review.title: Segmentation of optic disc, fovea and retinal vasculature using a single convolutional neural network
review.abstract: We have developed and trained a convolutional neural network to automatically and simultaneously segment optic disc, fovea and blood vessels. Fundus images were normalised before segmentation was performed to enforce consistency in background lighting and contrast. For every effective point in the fundus image, our algorithm extracted three channels of input from the neighbourhood of the point and forward the response across the 7 layer network. In average, our segmentation achieved an accuracy of 92.68 percent on the testing set from Drive database.

metadata.title: Segmentation of optic disc, fovea and retinal vasculature using a single convolutional neural network

sections.text: We developed and trained a convolutionary neural network for automatic and simultaneous segmentation of the optic disc, fovea and blood vessels. Fundus images were normalized before segmentation was performed to ensure consistency of backlight and contrast. For each effective point in the fundus image, our algorithm extracted three input channels from the vicinity of the point and relayed the response over the 7-layer network. The initial layer consists of four neurons representing the background, the optic disc, the fovea and the blood vessels. On average, our segmentation correctly classified 92.68% of the ground truths (on the test set from the Drive database), with the highest accuracy achieved on a single image being 94.54%, the lowest 88.85%. A single revolutionary neural network can be used not only to segment blood vessels, but also optic disc and fovea with good accuracy.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: We have developed an algorithm that can automatically and simultaneously segment all three areas. It consists of two parts: the normalization of the background and the 7-layer Convolutionary Neural Network. We have trained and tested our method on the DRIVE database, which has an average accuracy of 92.68%.
